5.text: Thank you for inviting me here to speak today

9.text: social responsibility in annual reports. A quick

13.text: overview of the presentation today. First I'll

15.text: speak a little bit about the history of annual

17.text: report discloses on work health and safety and

20.text: then give you some insights that we've found in

22.text: our research at Macquarie University into current

25.text: practices of reporting on work health and safety,

29.text: some examples of what's been done well,

31.text: some examples of things that haven't been done so well

33.text: and that gives us some insights into how we can

38.text: actually improve work health and safety reporting

41.text: in annual reports. So why the annual report?

44.text: The annual report is an excellent vehicle for

47.text: reporting on work health and safety. It's the main

49.text: medium that we use to communicate with our

52.text: external stakeholders and it's increasingly being

55.text: seen as a vehicle for investors to find out about

58.text: the way organisations manage risk, not just the

63.text: information such as work health and safety. In the

67.text: research that we have conducted, stakeholders see

69.text: the annual report as a particularly credible

71.text: source of information for reporting on work health

74.text: and safety, more so than sustainability reports

77.text: and more so than websites and other forms of

80.text: corporate media. There's actually quite a long

84.text: history of reporting work health and safety

86.text: information in annual reports. For example, I did

89.text: spend some time down at a library in Canberra

91.text: looking at the 1820s annual reports from the

93.text: Australian Agricultural and Pastoral Company where

98.text: they talked about people that had been off work

101.text: due to sickness and injury and illness, and this

105.text: is 1823 to 1825. Now even back then although

110.text: there was some reporting, it was very sporadic and

112.text: there was the occasional mention of gases in mines

117.text: and those sorts of things but it was really about

119.text: trying to highlight where companies had lost money

122.text: due to illness and injury or due to working conditions.

130.text: to see a real move towards corporate

132.text: social responsibility, and with that, there was an

135.text: explosion in the number of companies that were

137.text: reporting on health and safety in annual reports.

140.text: And there was increasing attention, but it's

143.text: really become mainstream in the last 10 to 15 years,

146.text: and it's not only the companies that are

149.text: now reporting on health and safety, but the public

151.text: has come to expect it. So, the issue is 'the quality'.

160.text: general is quite poor. In terms of the early research,

167.text: when we first started looking - and this

169.text: is particularly in the accounting discipline -

171.text: when we first started looking at annual report

174.text: information on work health and safety, in the

176.text: 1970s and '80s there was a lot of focus on,

179.text: "Is the information there?" So, "Do companies report

182.text: on health and safety - yes or no?" We started

185.text: counting pages and sentences and numbers of words

188.text: because that gave an indication of how much focus

191.text: or how much importance the companies placed on

193.text: those particular disclosures and on that information.

197.text: Then attention started to turn towards the

199.text: quality of information, so not just interested

202.text: in was it there but what sort of information was

205.text:
being provided,
and so organisations' reports

210.text: were being assessed and analysed in terms of was the

213.text: information just qualitative or quantitative, was it

217.text: full of motherhood statements and claims about - you know -

220.text: "We're best practice," or were they actually

221.text: providing information? So they were looking at,

224.text: "Is there positive news as well as negative news?",

229.text: information as well as qualitative?" More recently

234.text: that investigation of quality and quantity has

238.text: become more targeted and focused. The examination

243.text: is really looking now at the quality of content in

245.text: terms of is that information relevant to the users

249.text: that it's intended for? Is it reliable?

252.text: Is it verified? So no longer are those motherhood

256.text: statements about, "We look after the work health

258.text: and safety of our workers" enough. We now have to

262.text: go beyond that and we're looking for evidence.

266.text: One of the interesting issues around that is the issue

272.text: I'll talk in a few moments about some of the studies

274.text: we've been doing, but one of the interesting

276.text: things that we noticed in some of the reports

279.text: is we have seen reports where they say,

281.text: "We're going to link executive bonuses to work health

283.text: and safety performance and we're doing that because

287.text: that information is able to be measured objectively,

290.text: and it's easily verified." Yet in other reports

294.text: we looked at, they had independent assurance

297.text: of all of the social and environmental information,

300.text: but health and safety was explicitly excluded

303.text: from the scope of those audit reports,

307.text: and so that's been a really interesting issue to

308.text: look at in terms of why is that information being excluded.

315.text: The current research that we're doing at

316.text: the moment, we have two projects going looking at

318.text: work health and safety evaluation and reporting

321.text: sponsored by Safe Work Australia. Both are being

325.text: conducted with the Safety Institute of Australia

327.text: and we also have the Institute of Chartered Accountants

330.text: and CPA Australia involved in those projects.

334.text: And this work is informed by prior research

338.text: and the prior research has looked two aspects.

340.text: One, what do stakeholders want to see in reports?

344.text: What's important to the different stakeholder groups?

347.text: And secondly, what are companies actually providing?

352.text: And the examples I'll present today come from two studies

355.text: that you can see there - one is a study of mining and

358.text: energy firm disclosures over a period of 10 years

362.text: in annual and sustainability reports. The other study,

365.text: is a study of work health and safety

368.text: disclosures from a whole range of different

370.text: industries and they were large companies in the

373.text: ASX Top 50. What we found looking at both of those

378.text: content analysis studies is that in general

381.text: there's increasing evidence of reporting on work

383.text: health and safety in annual reports - although

386.text: there's a wide variation in the quality of that data.

390.text: And there is a substantial gap between what

392.text: the stakeholders are expecting to see and what

394.text: companies are actually reporting. And so these are

397.text: the issues that we'd really like to talk about today.

404.text: In terms of demonstrating governance - upfront,

407.text: this is the most important, the first thing

409.text: we should be looking at. Does the company value

412.text: work health and safety, and how does it express that?

416.text: When we looked annual reports, most of the firms

418.text: stated a commitment to work health and safety.

420.text: They had a statement in there that talked about

424.text: their vision, for example I've got an example

426.text: there from an annual report - number one -

428.text: "Nothing is more important to your Directors than

430.text: ensuring the safety and security of our employees."

433.text: Now we saw a lot of statements like that.

438.text: However, while they are important and they need to

440.text: be there, they're also very easy to write. So, they're

446.text: important but they are not sufficient. They need to be

449.text: backed up by evidence and you can see an

451.text: example we have there from another report

453.text: which talks about 'the committee reports to the

456.text: board and it talks about the structures', how that

458.text: governance is enacted. 'The auditors perform reviews,

461.text: there's written reports' and it starts to give

464.text: you some evidence for how governance is

469.text: So, adding that level of evidence is important.

472.text: Similarly, with reports on strategy some of the

475.text: organisations were very vague. "We continue to

478.text: reinforce our steadfast belief that we must never take

481.text: the health safety of our people for granted and

483.text: the pursuit of zero harm remains our overriding goal."

489.text: Aside from the arguments about whether zero harm -

492.text: we're not going to get into whether it's a goal,

494.text: a vision or an objective, but the idea that

498.text: we don't want to hurt people is obviously very important.

502.text: We need to see that, we need to know the company believes it.

505.text: However again, some evidence to justify, to explain that,

510.text: to show how they go about meeting that objective

514.text: is really important. And so some of the examples

516.text: we had there, and you can see, talking about

521.text: what's explained elsewhere in the annual report,

523.text: how they actually demonstrate what they're doing

525.text: about meeting that goal, continuous improvement projects,

529.text: talking about some of their risks, talking about

534.text: these are all very important things for investors

536.text: and other stakeholders to see. So the key there is

541.text: providing evidence. Now as we move from the early

545.text: '90s to the mid '90s, we started to get out of the

549.text: 'motherhood statements' and back it up with a

551.text: little bit of qualitative evidence. More recently

554.text: we've seen companies start to try and look at

556.text: leading indicators and that's a really important

559.text: way of providing evidence as to the effectiveness

563.text: of the processes and projects and initiatives that

566.text: have been put in place to manage health and safety.

571.text: In terms of leading and lagging indicators

573.text: we see a lot of reports that talk about injury

576.text: rates but there's very few that focus on the front

579.text: end there, the leading and lagging indicators of

582.text: the critical processes used to manage health and safety.

585.text: So for example, 'consultation'. A leading indicator

589.text: of consultation might be how many of staff

591.text: we have consulted about health and safety issues.

594.text: A lagging indicator or an effectiveness indicator

597.text: would be saying something about how many suggestions

601.text: offered by those staff have actually been adopted.

608.text: In the annual reports we tend to see a focus

610.text: on auditing, so the number of audits conducted.

613.text: We see a lot of evidence around training conducted.

616.text: We see very little in terms of the effectiveness

619.text: of audits or training and there's certainly

622.text: a lot of room for improvement there and we look

624.text: forward to seeing that happen in the future.

629.text: Unfortunately, where a lot of the reports do seem to

631.text: be stuck, and this has continued over nearly 20 years now,

635.text: we've seen an increasing number of firms reporting primarily

638.text: on injury and illness rates. Certainly, not saying

642.text: that's not important. We need to see that information.

645.text: However, there's a lot of focus on fatality

649.text: and lost time injury rates, and unfortunately,

652.text: that's not terribly helpful. We've seen a lot of new

656.text: companies coming into the realm of reporting on work

658.text: health and safety, look around and say

660.text: "What's everyone else reporting on?" - lost time injury,

663.text: so they join that sort of flock of lost time injury

667.text: advocates which has been a bit of a shame because it's not

669.text: a useful measure for reporting in annual reports,

673.text: and I'll just talk a little bit about why.

677.text: Lost time injury rates don't measure safety and they

680.text: certainly don't measure health and safety. Safety is about

683.text: 'the absence of risk of injury and illness', so the injury

687.text: rates will tell you if there has been an injury but they

691.text: won't tell you anything about the risk that's been there,

694.text: particularly if injury rates are low.

698.text: As well as that, lost time injury rates - they're only

702.text: a subset of injuries and illnesses. They fail to

706.text: capture most incidents, they don't capture

708.text: illnesses very well at all and they fail to

711.text: capture all the work-related injuries. So they're

713.text: not a valid measure of frequency and they don't capture

716.text: all of those injuries for a whole range of reasons,

718.text: whether it's underreporting or whether it's

720.text: that the injuries are captured in different

722.text: categories such as medical treatment injury.

726.text: They're also too aggregated to inform about the

729.text: consequences of injury. A lot of people will say

733.text: and we see it in annual reports all the time,

735.text: "We measure lost time injury rates," they say,

737.text: "because it tells us about our serious injuries,"

740.text: but that's not necessarily true because we could

743.text: have a permanent hearing loss for example,

745.text: which is a serious injury, and yet, if that person

748.text: hasn't had to take an entire day off work due to

751.text: that hearing loss, it won't be captured as a lost

754.text: time injury. It will be captured as medical

755.text: treatment which is perceived by many managers to

759.text: be a more minor classification. Similarly with

762.text: musculoskeletal injuries. Sometimes you can have

764.text: injuries where people will be affected for months, years,

768.text: even whole-of-life, due to say, a back injury

771.text: or a shoulder injury, and yet they may not

773.text: be captured as a lost time injury. So they're

775.text: viewed as a more minor category of injury.

783.text: So in terms of those measures, lost time injuries,

785.text: if they're not capturing illnesses, they're not

787.text: capturing severity or frequency very well. We then

791.text: thought we'd have a look and see, "Does that

793.text: actually work on a larger scale?" "Can we show -

796.text: demonstrate that that actually is the case, that they don't

799.text: capture severity very well?" So in one study that we've

804.text: completed fairly recently we took all of the data from

809.text: New South Wales workers compensation over a period

813.text: of 10 years and we graphed the injuries.

815.text: We graphed fatalities and we graphed lost time injuries,

819.text: and you can see there both of those are trending down.

823.text: And so that demonstrates that New South Wales

825.text: has been very successful in reducing fatalities and lost

828.text: time injuries over that period and that's what we want to see.

833.text: We then took exactly the same injuries and

835.text: we reclassed them. We classified them as either

842.text: and what we found was the temporarily disabling

845.text: injuries went down quite severely, but the

848.text: permanent disabilities almost doubled in that period,

852.text: and that data was completely hidden if we

855.text: were just looking at lost time injury rates.

858.text: And so this is the problem that we have in industry.

861.text: Most managers get lost time injury and fatality data,

864.text: and this is also the information that is

866.text: most commonly produced in annual reports to

868.text: investors and other stakeholders. So as a result,

871.text: the users of those reports aren't able to see the

873.text: information that could really tell them about the

876.text: consequences of work health and safety outcomes.

883.text: If we look at the traditional way that we would

885.text: view categories of injury and illness, Heinrich's triangle,

890.text: Bird's triangle, those kinds of traditional triangle

893.text: models that tell us that we have first aid

896.text: treatment which is the most minor,

897.text: we've got medical treatment, restricted duties and

900.text: then lost time injuries with fatalities at the top.

904.text: What we see from that is that lost time

906.text: injury rate aggregates a whole range of different

909.text: categories of the injury and illness, and a range

912.text: of different severities. By placing the triangle

916.text: that way up, it looks as though the focus and it

920.text: does direct the focus to the bottom of the triangle,

923.text: the most frequent injury and illnesses.

925.text: And so, in a sense we're trying to capture the

928.text: low-hanging fruit. We're trying to prevent the

932.text: short-term absences and the moderate absences.

936.text: This is a very production or work focused

943.text: reflect what the business does - Does it offer

945.text: first aid? Does it offer medical treatment?

947.text: Does it give the person time off? - and it fails to

950.text: focus on the outcomes. The consequences, both socially,

955.text: the consequences for the employees and

957.text: to a large extent, the consequences financially

960.text: for the organisation because if we look at the cost,

963.text: the costs of fatalities and permanent

965.text: disabilities are significantly higher than the

968.text: costs of short-term absences, and you're talking

972.text: about differences of over 80,000 for the disabilities

976.text: down to less than 1,000 for the minor injuries.

983.text: So, we've been looking at this alternate model and this

986.text: is a model developed by Jeff Macdonald many years ago.

990.text: It's been used around Australia in a number of organisations

993.text: and it's really looking at reframing the way we view

997.text: injury and illness. It turns the triangle upside

1001.text: down and it puts the focus on the injuries that

1004.text: are the highest consequence. Irrespective of how

1007.text: much time the person has had off work, it's about

1010.text: time to recovery, not time back to work. So class one

1016.text: are those most debilitating injuries and

1018.text: illnesses that cause a permanent disability or a fatality,

1021.text: or that have a long-term impact on the individual.

1026.text: Class two are the temporary impairments and

1030.text: class three are those that really don't

1031.text: have any sort of life altering difference,

1033.text: more of an inconvenience really. So, if we turn

1037.text: the triangle that way and we start looking at

1039.text: severity by saying, "Okay, we've got these total

1042.text: class one plus class two," essentially if you add

1045.text: them together it's going to be something very

1047.text: close to a TRIF - a total recordable injury rate

1051.text: because you've captured all of those injuries that

1053.text: are really everything over first aid, and we then can

1056.text: separate out class one, so we can identify which

1060.text: of those injuries that are going to have the most

1062.text: significant impact. It takes a human perspective.

1070.text: When we were looking at annual reporting studies,

1073.text: in the early '90s and mid '90s, we did see a number of

1076.text: organisations that were reporting class one.

1079.text: They didn't call it that, but they were reporting on

1081.text: not only fatalities, but permanently disabling injuries

1086.text: and also those that caused long-term impairment.

1091.text: However, we then saw this move towards lost time injuries

1095.text: and a lot of that permanent disability and serious

1098.text: injury reporting has disappeared. We saw some other

1103.text: issues in the reporting which are worth mentioning

1105.text: I think, in terms of injury and illness data quality,

1108.text: and that was around reliability and comparability issues.

1112.text: For example, different firms reported on different measures.

1116.text: Some would report lost time injuries, some would report

1118.text: medical treatment, some would report total recordables,

1121.text: some would report an all injury rate - so you really couldn't

1124.text: compare where they stood, make any sort of

1130.text: But it actually went further than that.

1133.text: The measures were very unstable and by that

1136.text: I mean, an organisation would produce a report that said,

1139.text: "Our lost time injury rates are 0.7 and that's

1141.text: favourable compared to last year which was 0.9."

1144.text: Then the next year they'd say, "Our lost time injury rate

1147.text: is 0.6 which is better than last year which was 0.7,"

1151.text: and then the next year you wouldn't see anything,

1153.text: and suddenly they'd produce something different.

1155.text: "This year we're talking about all injury," and after

1157.text: a few years they come back to reporting on lost time

1160.text: injury and show a trend graph and you realise that

1162.text: the year that they actually stopped reporting on it

1164.text: was a poor result. It had gone up. And so there was all

1168.text: this sort of manipulation in the way that the data

1171.text: was presented that they'd change from one to the

1173.text: other one when it didn't present them in a

1174.text: favourable light. So that was a bit of an issue.

1178.text: In terms of understanding and interpreting the

1180.text: measures that was also a bit of an issue because

1182.text: organisations would use the same name for two different

1186.text: types of measures. So, they would say,

1188.text: "Our LTIFR is this," someone else, "LTIFR is that"

1193.text: but when you look at the definitions that

1194.text: they used, they're measuring different things.

1197.text: They're measuring it differently. Some would say,

1200.text: "We have to have our insurance company accept it

1203.text: before it counts as a lost time injury rate."

1205.text: Some would say, "It includes illnesses, " others would

1208.text: say it wouldn't. Some would say, "It could be a

1210.text: period of time off work any time after the injury,"

1214.text: others would say, "It has to be the very next day."

1217.text: So there's a whole lot of different

1218.text: definitions being applied at the same indicator.

1221.text: And then we had the curious case of the same

1224.text: definition with different names which happened as well.

1227.text: Lost time incident versus lost time injury -

1230.text: are they the same thing? Is an incident also

1232.text: capturing illnesses or not? Sometimes injuries

1235.text: captured illnesses, sometimes they didn't, so it

1237.text: all got very messy when you're trying to

1238.text: understand what was actually being reported,

1241.text: and many organisations didn't even provide a

1244.text: definition which made it even more difficult to

1246.text: tell what they were measuring. So the use of a

1249.text: glossary in an annual report is absolutely

1251.text: critical to say what it is that you're actually

1254.text: trying to communicate to your readers. Here's a

1257.text: couple of examples. This is one study that we had done.

1260.text: We looked at annual reports and these are

1262.text: all the different definitions just for lost time

1264.text: injury rates that were produced in those reports,

1268.text: and the interesting thing is some of the companies

1270.text: changed the definition they used. You'll see the

1274.text: one that has the most - 25 different companies

1277.text: reported lost time injury rates in those selected periods

1281.text: but if you add the numbers of reporters across,

1285.text: they won't add up to 25 which means that you

1300.text: Some of the other issues that we found -

1302.text: and this is just things to ensure that

1305.text: the quality of your data is being produced to a

1310.text: high standard - checking that the numbers add up.

1315.text: annual report and a sustainability report for the

1317.text: same year. So they would issue the two reports at the same

1319.text:
time and one would say, "Our
lost time injury rate is..."

1323.text: you know, "...0.4" and the other one would say,

1329.text: It may be that they're looking at slightly

1336.text: We even had examples where they had two different

1338.text: rates in the same report and one example with two

1342.text: different rates on the same page, and I think this

1418.text: that's coming out doesn't really make sense.

1423.text: The other thing that we did notice was sometimes

1426.text: the narratives around the injuries and the illness

1429.text: data was a little bit interesting. An increase in

1432.text: injury rates in one report was described as

1437.text: "An increase in lost time injury rates was a slight improvement"

1441.text: which was a concern. So, I think if health and safety

1448.text: information is going in the reports,

1451.text: we do need to make sure that the health and safety people

1453.text: get to have a good look at it before it goes out because

1456.text: we can see those sorts of issues there could be picked

1459.text: up by people with a little bit more knowledge

1461.text: I think, about health and safety itself.

1464.text: In terms of the completeness 'consistency' is also

1467.text: really important. Fatalities - for example, companies were

1470.text: reporting fatalities when there were none and then saying,

1472.text: "We had none this year compared to one last year"

1475.text: but last year there wasn't one reported. Contractors -

1478.text: and this is I think, an important issue that's come

1480.text: out with the new Work Health and Safety Act and

1482.text: the idea of a PCBU - in the previous reports

1486.text: particularly around the late '90s and the early 2000s,

1489.text: companies would report employee and contractor

1491.text: injury data separately, when the contractors

1494.text: were worse than them, and they would

1497.text: report them together when the employees had

1501.text: poorer injury performance than the contractors.

1512.text: the contractors as part of the organisation and

1518.text: So I think that's a really useful thing,

1520.text: and I've already mentioned about permanent and

1545.text: actually the same performance in the two graphs because of

1562.text: information about the actual numbers of those injury rates.

1573.text: When we asked stakeholders what sort of financial information

1576.text: they wanted to see on work health and safety,

1578.text: that produced a really interesting result.

1581.text: Stakeholders were very clear that they wanted to see

1584.text: information about the financial costs of work health and

1586.text: safety failure. They wanted to know about fines and penalties.

1589.text: They wanted to know about the legal costs.

1593.text: Some wanted to know about workers compensation,

1595.text: not quite so much, but they were very clear

1598.text: that they didn't want - most of them didn't

1600.text: want reporting on costs to do with prevention

1604.text: and there was a genuine fear I think,

1606.text: coming through in the research that if companies

1609.text: started reporting how much money they were

1610.text: spending on prevention two things would happen - one,

1614.text: there'd be a focus on, "Are we spending too much?"

1616.text: and secondly, that there would be a whole

1619.text: exercise of trying to tease out health and safety

1622.text: costs from other cost categories which would be

1625.text: really not very useful in terms of adding value to

1629.text: the organisation. And, so I think the focus there

1632.text: for costs is really around the failure costs and

1634.text: that's important for a number of reasons. We saw

1637.text: with the BP Deepwater Horizon response from

1641.text: investors the year after the oil well explosion,

1645.text: the investors at the annual general meeting were saying,

1647.text: "Why aren't we getting the information we

1649.text: need on work health and safety?" , "Why didn't we

1651.text: know the state that this organisation was in,

1653.text: in terms of its health and safety performance?"

1655.text: and so I think that's really important to keep in mind.

1659.text: In terms of lost productivity, lost time injury

1662.text: rate if anything, it's a productivity measure.

1665.text: It's certainly not a safety measure.

1666.text: It's not really a good injury measure. More than

1668.text: anything it's a productivity measure, but it's

1671.text: only a partial productivity measure because it

1673.text: tells you how many injuries were reported that

1677.text: actually cost lost productivity. It doesn't tell

1680.text: you how much was lost, so if you are going to

1682.text: report it as a productivity measure, it needs to

1685.text: be matched with a measure of lost work days.

1688.text: It's like producing financial statements. You have a

1690.text: balance sheet and an income statement telling you

1693.text: about two different perspectives on your financial performance.

1695.text: The same with lost time injury rates.

1698.text: You would need to know the number, the frequency

1699.text: and also the severity. Better still, OSHA in the

1703.text: United States has a measure called the DART rate

1706.text: which is Days Away of Restricted and Transfer,

1709.text: and so that gives a more complete, holistic measure

1711.text: of lost time and it avoids some of the issues that we see

1714.text: with manipulation of things being treated as a restricted

1717.text: day when it should be a lost day or those sorts of temptations.

1723.text: In terms of comparability, over time, as we looked at

1727.text: the annual reports' trends over time, one of the key

1731.text: conclusions that I think came out of it is there's a

1733.text: real desire among organisations to be comparable,

1738.text: to be able to benchmark to provide information

1740.text: that's consistent and I think that's genuine

1742.text: and I think it's a useful thing. However, what we've seen

1745.text: is the comparability and consistency has really

1748.text: come out in a reduction in standards to look at a lost

1752.text: time injury rate and that's where the comparability

1755.text: has ended up, and I think that's a shame. So, instead of

1758.text: reporting a range of things that are specific to different

1761.text: organisations, we now see a real focus on lost

1764.text: time injury and fatality measures. There is an

1768.text: increasing focus on, just in the last few years,

1771.text: on a total recordable measure instead of lost time

1773.text: injuries and I think that's a good move. It is a

1777.text: more aggregated measure, so it does need severity

1779.text: data to accompany it and that's really important

1782.text: that the two of those come together. Without that,

1785.text: what we end up with is measures that hide the

1787.text: human and social impact and don't tell us anything

1790.text: about the effectiveness of work health and safety systems.

1798.text: I think that last point is the real opportunity

1801.text: for the future. It's really about trying

1804.text: to develop ways of reporting that are able

1806.text: to communicate the work health and safety systems,

1810.text: the effectiveness of those systems, the actions

1812.text: that are being taken, there's very few firms that

1815.text: are doing that well. There are some, but there's

1817.text: very few that are doing that well at the moment.

1822.text: So, demonstrating leadership - coming back to our topic -

1825.text: demonstrating leadership and corporate social responsibility.

1829.text: First of all, I think it's important to recognise who

1832.text: are the users of the report. We need to recognise that

1835.text: investors are important users. Employees - we often have

1839.text: students and people in our workshops that have

1842.text: told us over and again that when they're looking

1844.text: for new jobs, they're looking to move before they

1847.text: will move, they look at the annual report of the

1849.text: organisation that they're looking to work for,

1852.text: and they look at things like the work health and

1854.text: safety reporting, to see what the company is like

1857.text: as a potential employer. Customers and suppliers,

1863.text: it's important for them to see work health and

1865.text: safety information. Companies also need to consider their

1869.text: own needs and priorities, consider the needs and

1871.text: priorities of those users of the reports and I think

1874.text: with - in terms of the investors, in the

1878.text: last three years in particular we've seen a

1880.text: significant change in the way investors are viewing

1883.text: health and safety information in annual reports.

1885.text: They're very keen to see that information.

1888.text: They understand that companies that manage

1890.text: health and safety well are more likely to

1893.text: manage risk well, business risk, and I think

1896.text: that's an important point to recognise.

1901.text: In terms of demonstrating leadership through an

1903.text: annual report, it's not just about leading safety,

1906.text: it's about leading safely. So it's about showing that

1909.text: you can integrate work health and safety into the

1912.text: business operations, into decision making so that

1916.text: the aim of the activity, the leadership aim, is to

1920.text: really have safe, healthy and productive work.

1924.text: Corporate social responsibility - being open and

1926.text: honest about the impact and this is where the

1929.text: severity reporting comes in. Companies that are

1931.text: reluctant to talk about the severity of their

1933.text: injuries are really hiding the impact of their

1938.text: health and safety systems, and particularly the

1941.text: impact on the human side, the employees,

1944.text: the families and also the broader social impact

1947.text: through the externalities that they cause.

1952.text: So just in summary, work health and safety information in

1956.text: annual reports - if we're to demonstrate

1960.text: this requires a number of things. It requires an

1964.text: articulation of the mission, what it is the

1966.text: company is really trying to achieve.

1969.text: The companies, the organisations, also need to

1972.text: recognise what their critical risks are and be

1974.text: prepared to say, "This is the critical risks that

1977.text: we face in our organisation." We know what sort of

1980.text: risks different industries face. It's not like

1983.text: it's a surprise to the users of the report.

1985.text: The fact that companies don't often want to talk

1987.text: about them is something that will then raise more

1991.text: questions than answers. Once they talk about the risks,

1996.text: it's really important that they outline how

1998.text: they're managing them. It doesn't have to go into

2001.text: a lot of detail, but if companies can say,

2003.text: "This is our approach to managing risk" giving the

2006.text: reader some assurance that they've thought about it,

2009.text: that they have a plan and a strategy, and then

2012.text: acknowledging the consequences, the injuries and illnesses,

2015.text: not only the frequency but also the severity,

2018.text: to some extent the cost - the failure

2021.text: costs where relevant, and then finally,

2023.text: where there have been a serious injury or illness,

2029.text: "What was the cause?", "What did you find out

2031.text: about why that injury or illness happened?" and then

2033.text: "What's been done to prevent it happening again?"

2038.text: Again, it doesn't have to be long but it needs to be there.
